title.narrative: Sustaining Lifesaving Humanitarian Primary Health Interventions and Response to Cholera Outbreaks in Adamawa State

description.narrative:
This project will strengthen and scale-up existing primary health care services in Yola North, Yola South, Girei and Song LGAs of Adamawa State. It will also focus on strengthening the ongoing Cholera outbreak response (OBR) in the same locations.
UNICEF, in partnership with the Adamawa State Primary Health Care Development Agency (SPHCDA), will strengthen provision of an integrated package of primary health care services in IDP camp clinics as well as facilitation of referral services to secondary and tertiary health institutions. This will target children under five years old, women and their families both from IDP populations as well as those in surrounding communities. Funds from this grant will be used to enhance emergency primary health services delivery including the provision of medicines and supplies to overburdened health facilities which are specifically catering to vulnerable populations, a majority of whom are women and children.
UNICEF will support SPHCDA and the State Ministry of Health (SMoH) to provide emergency integrated PHC services which include: treatment of common diseases (malaria, RTI, diarrhea, etc.), provision of antenatal care and safe delivery services, immunization and referral services in IDP camp and host community clinics. To do this, UNICEF will work with the Adamawa State MOH, SPHCDA and other partners to address the critical gaps that hinder access to emergency primary health care services including addressing emerging challenges and critical needs. These needs include: inadequate number and distribution of health care workers, renovation/reconstruction of health facilities that have been damaged, poor storage capacity and dilapidated warehouses, poor logistics management system, lack of emergency drugs and supplies and the absence of referral systems due to lack of ambulances.
UNICEF, in partnership with the SPHCDA, will ensure that basic supplies and commodities, including provision of response medicines and support to medical staff required for effective Cholera OBR is available and prepositioned to reduce mortalities associated with the outbreak
